comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The RMS 'Niagara' (launched 1912, Union Steamship Company) was nicknamed "the Titanic of the Pacific", but after the sinking of the real RMS Titanic this was dropped in favour of "Queen of the Pacific", according to wikipedia - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RMS_Niagara . Sunk by a German mine off New Zealand in 1940 with a huge secret amount of gold on board, most of which they managed to salvage. I am hoping Frederick Wilkinson took a photo of the stern of the 'Niagara' too. Trying to id a ship which I think is the 'Niagara' at Pier One, see comments here - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5052578482/] And the unidentified liner photo - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=190056#

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Here you go! A pic of the stern of NIAGARA. What do you think? I think they look VERY similar, although the SLNSW image is a bit blurry.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Thanks so much! No big deal in the exercise but it proves (imho) that the 'Niagara' was one of the first ships at Pier One in 1913 on her maiden voyage. One day a clear shot of that stern view will surface at State Records NSW with a totally wrong title ... I came across a reference to the 'Niagara' being in Woolwich Dock in 1913, ten years earlier than this photo, when she was "easily the largest vessel which has ever been docked in Australia." SMH 11/7/1913 p.10 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15434785

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Wow - the vessel does look pretty impressive size-wise. I am sure more photos will turn up as digitisation continues to grow!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33102966@N06
comment._content: I have visited the dock often and am really surprised that it could accommodate a ship of this size.
